title: Tidy Tuesday - US Polling Places
text:
0. Loading Libraries

import pandas as pd
from dfply import *
from plotnine import *
import ssl



1. Data Loading

## adding below ssl line as it is giving ssl error locally in my machine
ssl._create_default_https_context = ssl._create_unverified_context

polling=pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-01-16/polling_places.csv")

2. Data Transformation

polling['year'] = polling['election_date'].apply(lambda x: int(x.split('-')[0]))

polling_summary = (polling >> group_by(X.year) >> summarize(count=n(X.year)) )



3. Plotting

(polling_summary >> 
 ggplot(aes(x = 'year', y = 'count')) + 
 geom_line() + theme_minimal() + 
 labs (
     x = "Year", 
     y = "No. of Polling Places",
     title = "Count of Polling Places",
     subtitle = "2012 to 2020"
 ) 
)

title: TidyTuesday Solved Soluitions
text:
This website is designed to showcase my solutions to TidyTuesday challenges. In the initial weeks, I will focus on basic analysis and plotting. As the weeks progress, I aim to provide more sophisticated and holistic solutions.
The coding is done in python majorly using the following packages as of now:

pandas
numpy
plotnine { Similar to that of ggplot of R }
dfply { Similar to that of tidyverse of R }




Tidy Tuesday Date
Dataset About
Link for my approach
Comments




16th Jan 2024
US Polling Places 2012-2020
Analysis-16012024
My first Basic Line Plot


30th Jan 2024
Groundhog predictions
Analysis-30012024
Density Plots


13th Feb 2024
Valentineâ€™s Day consumer data

title: Tidy Tuesday - GroundHog Predictions
text:
import pandas as pd
from dfply import *
from plotnine import *
import ssl

title: Tidy Tuesday - GroundHog Predictions
text:
3.1. Consensus of Groundhogs YonY


Code for Density Plot of Consensus
plot = (predictions_groundhog >>
        filter_by(X.shadow.notna()) >>
        ggplot(aes(x='year', color='shadow')) +
        geom_density() +
        scale_color_manual(name='Prediction',
                           labels=['Early Spring', 'Long Winter'],
                           values=['#8B4513', '#0000CD']) +
        theme_minimal(base_size=14) +
        theme(legend_position=(0.5, 0.5)) + 
        theme(figure_size=(6,4)) + 
        labs(title='Consensus of Groundhogs YoY'))

print(plot)

title: Tidy Tuesday - GroundHog Predictions
Tidy Tuesday - GroundHog Predictions
section: 3.3. Consensus of GroundHogs YonY by ShortName
text:
3.3. Consensus of GroundHogs YonY by ShortName


Code for Consensus Plot of Groundhogs by ShortName
plot = (predictions_groundhog >>
        filter_by(X.shadow.notna()) >>
        ggplot(aes(x='year', color='shadow')) +
        geom_histogram() +
        labs(title='Consensus of Groundhogs YoY') +
        facet_wrap('~shortname') +
        scale_color_manual(name='Prediction',
                           labels=['Early Spring', 'Long Winter'],
                           values=['#8B4513', '#0000CD']) + 
        theme_minimal(base_size = 14) + 
        theme(figure_size=(20,12))
                           )

print(plot)












I believe this is a simplified representation of the consensus to gain initial insights.

Considering the number of groundhogs included in the observational study, the majority predicted an early spring.
However, since we currently lack weather data, we are unable to cross-verify which predictions were accurate.
With the exception of Phil, most others forecasted an early spring.
